questions.neutral: Feels cooler down here, doesn't it?

hobby.message: Got a new origami fold in your pocket?
Political literature still whispering to you?
Get any ribbon for that antique typewriter yet?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: Feels like it, yes.
Couldn't help but notice the whispers. Seems quieter than usual.
Books have a certain weight these days, don't they?
A topic that's...close to my interests.
Not exactly the time for poetry, I suppose.
Certainly a change in the air.
Things aren't quite the same after recent events.
I've been reacquainting myself with old literature.
Printed pages seem to speak louder now.
Ever come across a book that defies the current climate?
The coolness is refreshing, Alex.
A shift, perhaps a reflection of these peculiar times.
Been delving into some banned political literature.
A hobby that's taken on new significance lately.
Recent happenings have added layers to past words, don't you think?
Yes, Alex, much cooler than up there.
Feels like the city's holding its breath after everything with Halden.
I've been collecting and restoring political texts, a bit of a treasure hunt.
Recent news made those banned words resonate differently.
You know, sometimes the past whispers truths we overlook today.
hobby_answer: I prefer the old stuff, when it was less risky to read, obviously.
Seems everyone is suddenly interested in old writings these days.
You know how it is—sometimes it's just desk decoration, not actual reading.
Let's just say I keep my interests to myself these days.
Nothing new, just reacquainting with the classics, you know.
Ah, found a text or two that needed a bit of love and care.
Seems like the political winds stirred the dust off some old shelves.
Kind of miss the days when literature stayed in its pages, though.
Just enjoying the usual, but with a more cautious eye lately.
Reading them now feels different with all this tension around.
Been sorting through some old pieces, a bit more tension than usual lately.
You can't beat the history in those old texts, even if the climate is a bit chilly.
With Halden's passing, I feel a bit of nostalgia for overlooked words.
Old works have a way of resurfacing in uncertain times.
I like seeing how words from the past speak to the present.
Found myself reconnecting with some texts as the city shifts in Halden's absence.
It's an odd time, watching how these old arguments flicker in new debates.
There's something grounding about old texts when the present feels unstable.
The recent disruptions had me pulling familiar old writings from the shelf.
As the system glitches, I find old wisdom surprisingly calming.
Lately, old texts, you know, they just feel comforting as uncertainty echoes around us.
Ironic, right? The city's most compliant alleys are where old words find their home these days.
Marek's passing had me reflecting on how much we owe to overlooked thoughts from the past.
Restoration of political texts feels like a subtle rebellion now, more relatable as things unravel.
There's wisdom in the margins of history, where systems like ours rarely tread.
